natural problem: Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job?
natural solution: In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 3"
shows  "fact n = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
 We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
 So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 3"
shows  "fact n = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the factorial of 3. The final answer is 6.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Alice Bob Carol :: person and president secretary treasurer :: job
assumes h0 : "distinct [Alice, Bob, Carol]"
and h1 : "distinct [president, secretary, treasurer]"
shows  "card {(a, b, c). a ∈ {Alice, Bob, Carol} ∧ b ∈ {Alice, Bob, Carol} ∧ c ∈ {Alice, Bob, Carol} ∧ a ≠ b ∧ a ≠ c ∧ b ≠ c} = 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
 We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
 So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.
 *)

theorem
fixes Alice Bob Carol :: person and president secretary treasurer :: job
assumes h0 : "distinct [Alice, Bob, Carol]"
and h1 : "distinct [president, secretary, treasurer]"
shows  "card {(a, b, c). a ∈ {Alice, Bob, Carol} ∧ b ∈ {Alice, Bob, Carol} ∧ c ∈ {Alice, Bob, Carol} ∧ a ≠ b ∧ a ≠ c ∧ b ≠ c} = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If Alice, Bob, and Carol are distinct people and there are three distinct jobs: president, secretary, and treasurer, how many different ways can these jobs be assigned if each person can only have one job? The final answer is 6.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P S T :: "'a set"
assumes h0 : "finite P \<and> finite S \<and> finite T"
and h1 : "card P = 1 \<and> card S = 1 \<and> card T = 1"
and h2 : "P \<inter> S = {} \<and> P \<inter> T = {} \<and> S \<inter> T = {}"
and h3 : "P \<union> S \<union> T = {Alice, Bob, Carol}"
shows  "fact (card (P \<union> S \<union> T)) = 6"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
 We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
 So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.
 *)

theorem
fixes P S T :: "'a set"
assumes h0 : "finite P \<and> finite S \<and> finite T"
and h1 : "card P = 1 \<and> card S = 1 \<and> card T = 1"
and h2 : "P \<inter> S = {} \<and> P \<inter> T = {} \<and> S \<inter> T = {}"
and h3 : "P \<union> S \<union> T = {Alice, Bob, Carol}"
shows  "fact (card (P \<union> S \<union> T)) = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are three sets P, S, and T. Each set contains only one unique person and no two sets have a person in common. The people are Alice, Bob, and Carol. Find the factorial of the total number of people. The final Answer is 6.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "'a \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "finite {Alice, Bob, Carol}"
and h1 : "card {Alice, Bob, Carol} = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall>x in {Alice, Bob, Carol}. f x \<le> 1"
shows  "card {f. bij_betw f {Alice, Bob, Carol} {President, Secretary, Treasurer}} = 6"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
 We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
 So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "'a \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "finite {Alice, Bob, Carol}"
and h1 : "card {Alice, Bob, Carol} = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall>x in {Alice, Bob, Carol}. f x \<le> 1"
shows  "card {f. bij_betw f {Alice, Bob, Carol} {President, Secretary, Treasurer}} = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: "How many ways can Alice, Bob, and Carol each be assigned a unique position of President, Secretary, or Treasurer? The answer is 6."

a_5.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes f :: "(string \<Rightarrow> string) set"
assumes h0 : "finite f"
and h1 : "card f = 3"
and h2 : "inj_on f (UNIV :: string set)"
shows  "card (Permutations f) = 6"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
 We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
 So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.
 *)

theorem 
fixes f :: "(string \<Rightarrow> string) set"
assumes h0 : "finite f"
and h1 : "card f = 3"
and h2 : "inj_on f (UNIV :: string set)"
shows  "card (Permutations f) = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Assume that there is a finite set $f$ of three distinct strings. If each string in the set $f$ is unique, how many different permutations of these strings exist? The final answer is 6.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Alice Bob Carol :: person and president secretary treasurer :: person
assumes h0 : "distinct [Alice, Bob, Carol]"
shows  "card {(president, secretary, treasurer). {president, secretary, treasurer} = {Alice, Bob, Carol}} = 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
 We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
 So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.
 *)

theorem
fixes Alice Bob Carol :: person and president secretary treasurer :: person
assumes h0 : "distinct [Alice, Bob, Carol]"
shows  "card {(president, secretary, treasurer). {president, secretary, treasurer} = {Alice, Bob, Carol}} = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In how many ways can Alice, Bob, and Carol be assigned the roles of president, secretary, and treasurer, assuming that each person holds exactly one position and each position is held by exactly one person? The answer is 6 ways.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "('a \<Rightarrow> bool) \<Rightarrow> 'a set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>A. P (\<lambda>x. x = 'Alice' \<or> x = 'Bob' \<or> x = 'Carol') A \<longrightarrow> card A = 3"
and h1 : "\<forall>A. P (\<lambda>x. x = 'President' \<or> x = 'Secretary' \<or> x = 'Treasurer') A \<longrightarrow> card A = 3"
and h2 : "finite {x. x = 'Alice' \<or> x = 'Bob' \<or> x = 'Carol'}"
shows  "card (SIGMA {x. x = 'Alice' \<or> x = 'Bob' \<or> x = 'Carol'} : {y. y = 'President' \<or> y = 'Secretary' \<or> y = 'Treasurer'}) = 6"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
 We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
 So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "('a \<Rightarrow> bool) \<Rightarrow> 'a set \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>A. P (\<lambda>x. x = 'Alice' \<or> x = 'Bob' \<or> x = 'Carol') A \<longrightarrow> card A = 3"
and h1 : "\<forall>A. P (\<lambda>x. x = 'President' \<or> x = 'Secretary' \<or> x = 'Treasurer') A \<longrightarrow> card A = 3"
and h2 : "finite {x. x = 'Alice' \<or> x = 'Bob' \<or> x = 'Carol'}"
shows  "card (SIGMA {x. x = 'Alice' \<or> x = 'Bob' \<or> x = 'Carol'} : {y. y = 'President' \<or> y = 'Secretary' \<or> y = 'Treasurer'}) = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Assume Alice, Bob, and Carol are three different people, and President, Secretary, and Treasurer are three different positions. If each person can hold each position, how many different combinations of positions can be assigned? The final answer is 6.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Alice Bob Carol :: person
shows  "card { (president, secretary, treasurer). president \<noteq> secretary \<and> president \<noteq> treasurer \<and> secretary \<noteq> treasurer \<and> {president, secretary, treasurer} = {Alice, Bob, Carol} } = 6"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
 We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
 So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.
 *)

theorem
fixes Alice Bob Carol :: person
shows  "card { (president, secretary, treasurer). president \<noteq> secretary \<and> president \<noteq> treasurer \<and> secretary \<noteq> treasurer \<and> {president, secretary, treasurer} = {Alice, Bob, Carol} } = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: How many ways can Alice, Bob, and Carol be assigned the roles of president, secretary, and treasurer, assuming that each person must hold exactly one position and no two people can hold the same position? The final answer is 6.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Alice Bob Carol :: 'a
assumes h0 : "distinct [Alice, Bob, Carol]"
shows  "card (permutations [Alice, Bob, Carol]) = 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given three members of a group -- Alice, Bob, and Carol -- in how many ways can these three be chosen to be the three officers (president, secretary, and treasurer) of the group, assuming no person holds more than one job? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 In this problem we are choosing a committee, so the order in which we choose the 3 people does not matter.
 We could have chosen them in any of the following orders (where A is Alice, B is Bob, and C is Carol): ABC, ACB, BAC, BCA, CAB, CBA.
 So each possible committee corresponds to $3! = \boxed{6}$ possible orderings.
 *)

theorem
fixes Alice Bob Carol :: 'a
assumes h0 : "distinct [Alice, Bob, Carol]"
shows  "card (permutations [Alice, Bob, Carol]) = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many different ways can Alice, Bob, and Carol be arranged in a line if all three of them are distinct? The final answer is 6.
